segment.source: Windows Runtime components
segment.target: Windows Runtime components

segment.source: Windows Runtime components are self-contained objects that you can instantiate and use from any language, including C#, Visual Basic, JavaScript, and C++.
segment.target: Windows Runtime components are self-contained objects that you can instantiate and use from any language, including C#, Visual Basic, JavaScript, and C++.

segment.source: Windows Runtime components
segment.target: Windows Runtime components

segment.source: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.
segment.target: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.

segment.source: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]
segment.target: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]

segment.source: Windows Runtime components are self-contained objects that you can instantiate and use from any language, including C#, Visual Basic, JavaScript, and C++.
segment.target: Windows Runtime components are self-contained objects that you can instantiate and use from any language, including C#, Visual Basic, JavaScript, and C++.

segment.source: You can use Visual Studio and C#, Visual Basic, or C++ to create Windows Runtime components that can be used in Universal Windows Platform (UWP) apps.
segment.target: You can use Visual Studio and C#, Visual Basic, or C++ to create Windows Runtime components that can be used in Universal Windows Platform (UWP) apps.

segment.source: Topic
segment.target: Topic

segment.source: Description
segment.target: Description

segment.source: Creating Windows Runtime Components in C++
segment.target: Creating Windows Runtime Components in C++

segment.source: This article shows how to use C++ to create a Windows Runtime component, which is a DLL that's callable from a Universal Windows app that's built by using JavaScript—or C#, Visual Basic, or C++.
segment.target: This article shows how to use C++ to create a Windows Runtime component, which is a DLL that's callable from a Universal Windows app that's built by using JavaScript—or C#, Visual Basic, or C++.

segment.source: Walkthrough: Creating a basic Windows Runtime component in C++ and calling it from JavaScript or C
segment.target: Walkthrough: Creating a basic Windows Runtime component in C++ and calling it from JavaScript or C

segment.source: This walkthrough shows how to create a basic Windows Runtime Component DLL that's callable from JavaScript, C#, or Visual Basic.
segment.target: This walkthrough shows how to create a basic Windows Runtime Component DLL that's callable from JavaScript, C#, or Visual Basic.

segment.source: Before you begin this walkthrough, make sure that you understand concepts such as the Abstract Binary Interface (ABI), ref classes, and the Visual C++ Component Extensions that make working with ref classes easier.
segment.target: Before you begin this walkthrough, make sure that you understand concepts such as the Abstract Binary Interface (ABI), ref classes, and the Visual C++ Component Extensions that make working with ref classes easier.

segment.source: For more information, see Creating Windows Runtime Components in C++ and Visual C++ Language Reference (C++/CX).
segment.target: For more information, see Creating Windows Runtime Components in C++ and Visual C++ Language Reference (C++/CX).

segment.source: Creating Windows Runtime Components in C# and Visual Basic
segment.target: Creating Windows Runtime Components in C# and Visual Basic

segment.source: Starting with the .NET Framework 4.5, you can use managed code to create your own Windows Runtime types, packaged in a Windows Runtime component.
segment.target: Starting with the .NET Framework 4.5, you can use managed code to create your own Windows Runtime types, packaged in a Windows Runtime component.

segment.source: You can use your component in Universal Windows Platform (UWP) apps with C++, JavaScript, Visual Basic, or C#.
segment.target: You can use your component in Universal Windows Platform (UWP) apps with C++, JavaScript, Visual Basic, or C#.

segment.source: This article outlines the rules for creating a component, and discusses some aspects of .NET Framework support for the Windows Runtime.
segment.target: This article outlines the rules for creating a component, and discusses some aspects of .NET Framework support for the Windows Runtime.

segment.source: In general, that support is designed to be transparent to the .NET Framework programmer.
segment.target: In general, that support is designed to be transparent to the .NET Framework programmer.

segment.source: However, when you create a component to use with JavaScript or C++, you need to be aware of differences in the way those languages support the Windows Runtime.
segment.target: However, when you create a component to use with JavaScript or C++, you need to be aware of differences in the way those languages support the Windows Runtime.

segment.source: Walkthrough: Creating a Simple Windows Runtime component and calling it from JavaScript
segment.target: Walkthrough: Creating a Simple Windows Runtime component and calling it from JavaScript

segment.source: This walkthrough shows how you can use the .NET Framework with Visual Basic or C# to create your own Windows Runtime types, packaged in a Windows Runtime component, and how to call the component from your Universal Windows app built for Windows using JavaScript.
segment.target: This walkthrough shows how you can use the .NET Framework with Visual Basic or C# to create your own Windows Runtime types, packaged in a Windows Runtime component, and how to call the component from your Universal Windows app built for Windows using JavaScript.

segment.source: Raising Events in Windows Runtime components
segment.target: Raising Events in Windows Runtime components

segment.source: If your Windows Runtime component raises an event of a user-defined delegate type on a background thread (worker thread) and you want JavaScript to be able to receive the event, you can implement and/or raise it in one of these ways:
segment.target: If your Windows Runtime component raises an event of a user-defined delegate type on a background thread (worker thread) and you want JavaScript to be able to receive the event, you can implement and/or raise it in one of these ways:
